Award.AwardTitle: Statistical Analysis of Complex, Highly-structured Functional Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
Functional data, where the observational units represent curves, surfaces, or images, are becoming increasingly prevalent in modern measurement systems. While most statistical methods focus on simplifying assumptions such as independence, real-world functional data often contain far more complex structures. For example, in neuroimaging, the dependence network across brain regions needs to be characterized using graphs based on EEG or fMRI measurements; in proteomic and spectral analysis, researchers frequently encounter functional data with featured regions. These structures represent generic complexities in data that cannot be handled by existing analytical tools. This project focuses on the development of novel statistical theory and methods to model complex structures. The proposed tools will be applied to datasets from neuroimaging, mass spectrometry, genomics, and bioinformatics. The research will be integrated with various educational and outreach activities that will impact teaching and learning both within and beyond the university.

The project has the following four interrelated objectives: (1) Develop a functional graphical model framework to characterize conditional independent relationships between random functions, and apply the methods to estimate large-scale brain networks; (2) Develop novel frequentist regularization strategies and Bayesian priors to select regions of functional data; (3) Use Markov random fields to characterize spatial dependency between functions, and apply them to functional areal and functional point-reference data; and (4) Educate and engage students in the field of high-dimensional data analysis, develop K-12 outreach programs, and mentor minority students.

Intellectual merit.  Modern high-throughput technologies produce various complex data in functional form, with basic observational units being curves, surfaces, or images sampled on a discrete grid.  While these data provide a rich source of information, they also pose extraordinary challenges to statistical methodology, mostly due to their ultra-high dimensionality and complex structures. It is not just desirable, but essential that analytical tools should be flexible to accommodate complex data structures and scalable to the increasing size and dimensionality.  This grant has allowed the PI and her collaborators to develop a suit of novel statistical theory and methods to extract useful information out of high-dimensional functional data while accounting for their intricate structures.  The specific data structures the PI studied include the conditional independence relationships between random functions, the spatial-temporal correlations, and the local regions that reflect systematic differences across groups. In addition to modeling the complex data structures, the PI has particularly focused on developing computational tools that allow effective compression and high-performance computing. The methods developed have been applied to solve a large scope of application problems in the area of brain imaging, proteomics, bioinformatics, and biosonar sensing.  

Broader impacts. By offering flexible and scalable statistical methods and computational tools, this project helps to advance discovery and understanding of complex structured functional data emerging in various applications fields, such as neuroscience, biomedical science, and bioengineering. In addition to the research development, another major component of this project is to educate and engage student at both university and K-12 levels through teaching, mentoring and outreach activities. Three PhD students, one master student, and one undergraduate student have been involved in this research. Among these five students, three are women. Two PhD dissertations have been completed, and the related research has been presented at professional conferences by students. The PI has also demonstrated her research products to K-12 students via virtual reality by collaborating with the Kids’ Tech University program and the university library at Virginia Tech.
